title: ChemInform Abstract: The Ce2Li0.39Ni1.61Si2Structure as a New Derivative of the AlB2Family.

reference.article-title: The Ce2Li0.39Ni1.61Si2 Structure as a New Derivative of the AlB2 Family.
reference.author: Stetskiv
reference.journal-title: Acta Crystallogr., Sect. C: Cryst. Struct. Commun.

short-container-title: Acta Crystallogr C Cryst Struct Commun
Acta Crystallogr Sect C Struct Chem
Acta Cryst Sect C Struct Chem
Acta Crystallogr Sect C Cryst Struct Commun
items.abstract: <jats:p>A new quaternary dicerium lithium/nickel disilicide, Ce<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>Li<jats:sub>0.39</jats:sub>Ni<jats:sub>1.61</jats:sub>Si<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>, crystallizes as a new structure type of intermetallic compounds closely related to the AlB<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>family. The crystal–chemical interrelationships between parent AlB<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>-type, BaLiSi, ZrBeSi and the title compound are discussed using the Bärnighausen formalism. Two Ce atoms occupy sites of 3<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>. symmetry. The remainder,<jats:italic>i.e.</jats:italic>Ni, mixed Ni/Li and Si atoms, occupy sites of \overline{6}<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>2 symmetry. The environment of the Ce atom is an 18-vertex polyhedron and the Ni, Ni/Li and Si atoms are enclosed in tricapped trigonal prisms. The title structure can be assigned to class No. 10 (trigonal prism and its derivatives) according to the Krypyakevich classification scheme [Krypyakevich (1977). In<jats:italic>Structure Types of Intermetallic Compounds</jats:italic>. Moscow: Nauka]. The electronic structure of the title compound was calculated using the tight-binding linear muffin-tin orbital method in the atomic spheres approximation (TB-LMTO-ASA). Metallic bonding is dominant in this compound. The strongest interactions are Ni—Si and Ce—Si.</jats:p>
title: The Ce2Li0.39Ni1.61Si2structure as a new derivative of the AlB2family

reference.unstructured: Andersen, O. K., Jepsen, O. & Glötzel, D. (1985). In Highlights of Condensed Matter Theory, edited by F. Bassani, F. Fumi & M. P. Tosi, pp. 59-176. New York: North-Holland.
Brandenburg, K. (2006). DIAMOND. Crystal Impact GbR, Bonn, Germany.

Gladyshevskii, E. I., Bodak, O. I. & Pecharskii, V. K. (1990). Phase Equilibria and Crystal Chemistry in Ternary Rare Earth Systems with Metallic Elements, in Handbook on the Physics and Chemistry of Rare Earths, edited by K. A. Gschneidner Jr & L. Eyring, Vol. 13, pp 1-190. Amsterdam: Elsevier Science Publishers BV.
Krypyakevich, P. I. (1977). In Structure Types of Intermetallic Compounds. Moscow: Nauka.
Oxford Diffraction (2008). CrysAlis CCD. Oxford Diffraction Ltd, Abingdon, Oxfordshire, England.

title: ChemInform Abstract: Tm2.22Co6Sn20and TmLi2Co6Sn20Stannides as Disordered Derivatives of the Cr23C6Structure Type.

reference.article-title: Tm2.22Co6Sn20 and TmLi2Co6Sn20 Stannides as Disordered Derivatives of the Cr23C6 Structure Type.
reference.author: Stetskiv
reference.journal-title: Acta Crystallogr., Sect. C: Cryst. Struct. Commun.

short-container-title: Acta Crystallogr C Cryst Struct Commun
Acta Crystallogr Sect C Cryst Struct Commun
items.abstract: <jats:p>A new ternary dithulium hexacobalt icosastannide, Tm<jats:sub>2.22</jats:sub>Co<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>Sn<jats:sub>20</jats:sub>, and a new quaternary thulium dilithium hexacobalt icosastannide, TmLi<jats:sub>2</jats:sub>Co<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>Sn<jats:sub>20</jats:sub>, crystallize as disordered variants of the binary cubic Cr<jats:sub>23</jats:sub>C<jats:sub>6</jats:sub>structure type (<jats:italic>cF</jats:italic>116). 48 Sn atoms occupy sites of<jats:italic>m.m</jats:italic>2 symmetry, 32 Sn atoms sites of .3<jats:italic>m</jats:italic>symmetry, 24 Co atoms sites of 4<jats:italic>m.m</jats:italic>symmetry, eight Li (or Tm in the case of the ternary phase) atoms sites of \overline{4} 3m symmetry and four Tm atoms sites of m \overline{3} m symmetry. The environment of one Tm atom is an 18-vertex polyhedron and that of the second Tm (or Li) atom is a 16-vertex polyhedron. Tetragonal antiprismatic coordination is observed for the Co atoms. Two Sn atoms are enclosed in a heavily deformed bicapped hexagonal prism and a monocapped hexagonal prism, respectively, and the environment of the third Sn atom is a 12-vertex polyhedron. The electronic structures of both title compounds were calculated using the tight-binding linear muffin-tin orbital method in the atomic spheres approximation (TB–LMTO–ASA). Metallic bonding is dominant in these compounds, but the presence of Sn—Sn covalent dumbbells is also observed.</jats:p>
title: Tm2.22Co6Sn20and TmLi2Co6Sn20stannides as disordered derivatives of the Cr23C6structure type
